text: judicial elections their routine in the
US but virtually unheard of in the rest
of the world now the Supreme Court
tackles how US judges will be elected in
the future that's a very curious thing
to say you're gonna have an independent
judiciary but at the same time one
accountable to the electorate supreme
court correspondent adam Liptak on
williams you levy the Florida Bar now on
the New York Times minute the specific
question at issue is whether judges can
personally solicit campaign money the
question is how closely tied is the
judge to that money whether the judge
can personally say to somebody please
help me get elected and whether that
does damage to the integrity of the
judicial system those arguing for a ban
on judicial fundraising believe it would
stop corruption the more judicial
campaigns look like general political
campaigns the more some people think
people are not getting a fair hearing
but one influenced by the money involved
in electing judges on the other side the
lawyers for the woman who brought the
case argued that barring fundraising
speeches and mass fundraising mailings
censors free speech the argument is that
if you're gonna have elections the First
Amendment plays a role and the First
Amendment has to allow judges to
campaign in a way that their messages
are heard so it's a clash between these
two values the free speech value on the
one hand and judicial independence and
integrity on the other with a decision
expected by summer the larger question
is what a judge's role really is are
they detached from politics and marked
by their technical skills or are they
just like any other elected official for
now many signs point to a ruling that
may further loosen campaign restrictions
that's been the trend among the federal
courts looking at these issues and it
will make judicial elections look more
like any other election see
